sections.heading: Quick Start: What to Know for the Exam
content: • Knowing which license is required (and when another license is ALSO required, like real estate or motor vehicle).
• Exemptions: what IS exempt and what is NOT exempt (especially online bidding vs simulcast).
• Timelines and numbers: renewal cycle, CE hours, lien/citation deadlines, recovery fund caps.
• Discipline triggers: escrow/commingling, misrepresentation, false bidders, written contracts, and who can accept compensation.
• Auction math: buyer’s premium, sales tax rules, commission splits, and escrow math.

sections.heading: License Requirements (62-19-102)
content: Big idea: If you act as an auctioneer (or advertise/represent that you are), you must hold the correct license.

sections.heading: Key rules:
content: • You cannot act as, advertise as, or represent yourself as an auctioneer without a valid license issued by the Commission.

• Real property auctions: you must be licensed under this chapter AND also hold the appropriate real estate broker/affiliate broker license. If an affiliate auctioneer is conducting the real property auction, the employing auctioneer must be on the premises during the auction.
• Public automobile auctions: you must be licensed as a public automobile auctioneer AND be licensed as a motor vehicle dealer under Title 55.
• All auctions arranged by or through a principal auctioneer must be conducted exclusively by individuals licensed under this chapter.

sections.heading: Exemptions (62-19-103)
content: Exemptions are fact-specific. If a question says “charity auction” or “court-ordered sale,” don’t assume. Check the conditions.
• Court-appointed roles (receiver, trustee in bankruptcy, guardian, executor, etc.) acting under court order.
• Trustee under trust agreement/deed of trust/will, or secured party selling collateral after default under UCC Article 9.
• Governmental entity auctions or judicial order/decree auctions.
• Political party/church/charitable auctions ONLY if the person conducting receives no compensation and does not hold themselves out as available to auction goods.
• Owner selling their own property in the regular course of managing/investing in property not acquired for resale (with a sales-tax presumption rule in the statute).
• Certain livestock and tobacco warehouse auctions, with conditions.
• Online fixed price or timed listings that allow bidding BUT are not a simulcast of a live auction.
• Certain salvage/nonrepairable vehicle auction businesses licensed under the Tennessee Motor Vehicle Commission, with conditions.
• Small online-auction activity threshold exemption: under $25,000 revenue in a calendar year from online auctions.

sections.heading: Tennessee Auctioneer Commission: What It Is and What It Does (62-19-104 to 62-19-107)
content: You’ll see questions about who sits on the Commission, quorum, and what powers it has.

sections.heading: Commission composition (high-yield):
content: • 5 members total.
• 4 members must be auctioneers: actively and principally engaged for at least 5 years, recognized standing, at least age 30, good moral character.
• 1 member is a public member (not engaged in the auction business): at least age 30, good moral character, appointed at-large.
• Governor appoints members and strives to have at least one member age 60 or older.
• Commission meets at least quarterly; 3 members = quorum.

sections.heading: Commission powers (high-yield):
content: • Organize itself and select officers.
• Adopt bylaws/rules/regulations consistent with law.
• Adopt a seal and keep records (copies can be used as evidence like originals).
• Set continuing education requirements and standards (with specific statutory exemptions).

sections.heading: Licensing Path and Exam Logistics (Student-Friendly)
content: The exam is part of the licensing process. Tennessee’s public licensing site and Commission pages outline the steps.

sections.heading: Typical path (affiliate-level entry point):
content: • Complete a 50-hour approved auction education program and obtain your education certificate.
• Apply to the testing company (PSI) to take the examination.
• After you pass, submit your fees and documentation to the Tennessee Auctioneer Commission for license issuance.
• Affiliate auctioneers need a sponsor (principal auctioneer actively licensed at least 1 year, per the licensing guidance).

sections.heading: Common fees shown on the state licensing guidance (verify current amounts at application time):
content: Note: Fees can change. Always confirm on the official Tennessee Department of Commerce and Insurance pages before collecting money from students.

sections.heading: Renewals and Continuing Education (62-19-106(e) and 62-19-111(i)-(j))
content: Renewal is time-based and unforgiving. Put these numbers on flashcards.
• Licenses expire two (2) years from the original issue date.
• Continuing education is six (6) hours each renewal period (unless you fall under a statutory exemption).
• Renewal is due on or before expiration. The Commission may allow renewal within two (2) months after expiration with fees and penalties. After that, you generally reapply.
• The state’s renewal guidance commonly indicates renewals are allowed in the 60 days immediately preceding expiration (check the current renewal instructions).

sections.heading: Statutory CE exemptions (from the text you provided):
content: • Auctioneer is exempt if age 60+ and licensed as an auctioneer for 10+ years.
• Auctioneer is exempt if licensed pursuant to this chapter since July 1, 1999.
• Auctioneer is exempt if holding only a bid caller license.
• No affiliate auctioneer is exempt from continuing education.

sections.heading: Discipline: Denial, Suspension, Revocation (62-19-112)
content: If you’re studying ethics, start here. The exam loves these scenarios.

sections.heading: Top discipline triggers to memorize:
content: • Substantial misrepresentation (including bid caller holding themselves out as principal/public automobile auctioneer).
• Flagrant course of misrepresentation or false promises.
• Affiliate auctioneer accepting compensation from anyone other than their employer auctioneer.
• Failing to account for/remit money belonging to others; commingling; failing to keep others’ funds in escrow/trust account (with a specific carveout for certain auto auctions).
• Failing to provide copies of written instruments at execution.
• Failing to enter into a written contract with the owner/consignee before sale.
• Engaging in real property auctioning without proper real estate licensure.
• Knowingly using false bidders/cappers/pullers.
• Improper, fraudulent, incompetent, or dishonest dealings.
• Bid caller negotiating/executing auction contracts or taking possession of seller assets or proceeds.
Practical exam tip: If the question asks “who can accept money,” look for the employer relationship, escrow handling, and whether the person is a bid caller vs affiliate vs principal.

sections.heading: Liens and Collection Rights (62-19-108 and 62-19-119)
content: These sections are numbers-heavy and easy points if you memorize the timelines.
• If an auctioneer is denied payment for commission/fee, they may have a lien on the property they were hired to auction (only property owned by the person who denied payment).
• Lien notice must be filed within 60 days after the auction in the county register’s office where the property is located.
• Lien is not effective against a bona fide purchaser for value.
• Lien continues for 90 days from filing and through the final termination of an enforcement suit filed within that period.
• To sue for compensation for auctioneering services, the person must allege and prove they were duly licensed at the time the cause of action arose.

• Affiliate auctioneers generally cannot sue in their own name for commissions from third parties; the employing auctioneer brings the action (affiliate can sue the employing auctioneer for amounts due).

sections.heading: Citations and Penalties (62-19-121 and 62-19-126)
content: This is enforcement mechanics: who can cite, deadlines, penalty range, and appeal timing.
• Violations are a Class C misdemeanor (criminal).
• Administrative director/investigator can issue citations for unlicensed activity.
• Citations include a cease-violations order and civil penalty of $50 to $2,500 per violation.
• Citation must be issued within 1 year of the act/omission.
• Appeal by written notice postmarked within 15 working days after service.
• If contested, a contested case hearing occurs under the Uniform Administrative Procedures Act.
• After appeals, the administrative director can seek court judgment for the civil penalty plus court costs and an order to cease violations.

sections.heading: Auctioneer Education and Recovery Account (62-19-116)
content: This is essentially a consumer protection fund. Memorize caps and the repayment consequence.
• Account minimum balance: $150,000.
• New and renewal licenses include a $50 fee (or lesser amount set by rule) to support the account.
• Court-ordered recovery is limited to actual/compensatory damages (not interest/costs).
• Max liability: $10,000 per transaction; max $20,000 aggregate on behalf of a licensee.
• If the account pays on behalf of a licensee, the Commission can suspend/revoke and require repayment plus interest before the person is eligible for a new license.
• Filing false or materially misleading documents related to the account is unlawful.

sections.heading: Reciprocity and Nonresidents (62-19-117)
content: If you see “out-of-state auctioneer,” think: reciprocity + escrow + service of process consent.
• Nonresident auctioneers regularly engaged in the business and maintaining a business location in another state may not have to maintain a TN business location (if they qualify under the statute).
• Commission may recognize another state’s license if: the person is domiciled there, that state reciprocates, and their requirements include an exam equal or higher standard than TN.
• Nonresident auctioneers must maintain an escrow account for others’ funds resulting from a TN auction sale.
• Nonresident applicants must file an irrevocable consent to service of process via the Commission and follow the statute’s mailing and default-judgment timing rules.

sections.heading: Business Location and Signage (62-19-118)
content: The exam loves letter-height questions. Yes, really.
• Maintain a definite place of business in Tennessee unless a nonresident exception applies.
• Maintain a conspicuous sign at/near outside entrance of principal and branch offices.
• Letters must be at least 2 inches high and clearly show the person’s name and indicate auctioneer/auction business.
• Multi-story office directory listing can satisfy the sign requirement.
• Commission may waive requirements for conflicts with local ordinances or unusual circumstances.

sections.heading: Public Automobile Auctions: Minimum Requirements (62-19-128)
content: This section is compliance-heavy. When you see vehicles, titles, and dealer licensing, slow down and read carefully.
• Must be licensed and regulated by both the Tennessee Auctioneer Commission and the Tennessee Motor Vehicle Commission when engaged in motor vehicle sales.

• Examples of minimum requirements include: zoning compliance letter, garagekeeper’s liability insurance ($500,000 minimum), surety bond ($50,000), compiled financial statement (not older than 12 months), minimum net worth ($100,000), and business telephone in the auction company name (cell phones not acceptable).
• Permanent professional sign letters must be at least 8 inches tall.
• Must sell only at the established place of business listed on the motor vehicle dealer license.
• May not sell new/unused vehicles or vehicles with manufacturer’s statement of origin.
• Must verify clean/unencumbered title history before vehicle is subject to auction.
• Auction must take possession of and retain title to each vehicle offered; if sold, title transfers through the auction to the buyer on the date of sale; if not sold, return unsigned title to owner.

sections.heading: What the Exam Commonly Tests (Based on 62-19-111(e))
content: The statute lists exam topics. Treat this as your blueprint.
• Reading, writing, spelling
• Elementary arithmetic (auction math)
• Elementary principles of land economics
• Ethics
• Tennessee law relating to bulk sales, auctions, brokerage
• Provisions of Title 62, Chapter 19
Note: The principal auctioneer exam is described as more specific in nature and scope than the affiliate exam.

sections.heading: Auction Math Mini-Guide (High Yield)
content: Practice until your brain does these on autopilot. Most test math is straightforward, but it punishes rushed reading.

sections.heading: Core formulas:
content: • Buyer’s premium = hammer price × premium rate.
• Sales tax (if stated as on hammer only) = hammer price × tax rate.
• Total buyer cost = hammer + buyer’s premium + applicable taxes/fees (based on the question).
• Commission due = hammer price × commission rate (or net-to-seller rules as stated).

sections.heading: Worked example (hammer-only tax):
content: Exam trap: Some questions tax the premium too. Only do that if the question says so.
